evidence.source_document: Brief in Support of Motion for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction
evidence.text: Plaintiffs Susan Webber and Jonathan St. Goddard are members of the Blackfeet Tribe, which has historic homelands from the Yellowstone River in Montana north to the North Saskatchewan River in Canada.

extracted.value: Plaintiffs Susan Webber and Jonathan St. Goddard are members of the Blackfeet Tribe, whose historic homelands span from the Yellowstone River in Montana north to the North Saskatchewan River in Canada.

evidence.source_document: Brief in Support of Motion for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction
evidence.text: The Canada Orders declare authority to act under: the Constitution; the laws of the United States of America, including the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (50 U.S.C. 1701 et seq) (IEEPA); the National Emergencies Act (50 U.S.C. 1601 et seq) (NEA); section 604 of the Trade Act of 1974, as amended (19 U.S.C. 2483); and section 301 of title 3.

extracted.value: The Canada Orders (Executive Order 14193 and Proclamations 10896 and 10895) declare authority to impose tariffs on all products entering the United States, citing the Constitution, IEEPA, NEA, Trade Act 1974, and Title 3.

evidence.source_document: Brief in Support of Motion for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction
evidence.text: The Canada Orders are invalid in their entirety, and this Court should enjoin them for two reasons: First, the Orders exceed the President’s constitutional and statutory authority and violate the separation of powers.

evidence.source_document: Brief in Support of Motion for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction
evidence.text: The Canada Orders violate Native American trade rights recognized by the Jay Treaty of 1794.

extracted.value: The Canada Orders are invalid in their entirety, violating the President’s constitutional and statutory authority, the separation of powers, and the Jay Treaty of 1794.

evidence.source_document: Brief in Support of Motion for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction
evidence.text: On April 2, 2025, new tariffs were imposed that are universal, sweeping, and random, applying to every country in the world other than Russia and North Korea.

extracted.value: The tariffs imposed by the Canada Orders are universal, sweeping, and random, applying to every country other than Russia and North Korea, effective April 5, 2025.

evidence.source_document: Brief in Support of Motion for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction
evidence.text: The tariffs have been paused, reinstated, partially paused, then put back on.

extracted.value: Tariffs have been paused, reinstated, partially paused, and then re‑imposed, creating uncertainty for affected parties.

evidence.source_document: Brief in Support of Motion for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction
evidence.text: Plaintiffs have suffered an injury in fact from the tariffs, and their injury will be redressed by the Court’s favorable decision on the Plaintiffs’ request for an injunction.

extracted.value: Plaintiffs have suffered an injury in fact from the tariffs, including increased costs for cross‑border trade and goods.

evidence.source_document: Brief in Support of Motion for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction
evidence.text: Border Patrol Nelson told St. Goddard the tariff charge would be $308.77. He said 25% tariff but didn’t clarify what the 25% was for or why it was being charged.

evidence.source_document: Brief in Support of Motion for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction
evidence.text: The replacement wheel cost $1,252.89 Canadian dollars. ... Border Patrol Nelson converted the invoice to U.S. Dollars, and then calculated the tariff. The tariff charge would be $308.77.

extracted.value: Jonathan St. Goddard, a Blackfeet rancher, paid a $308.77 tariff on a replacement tractor wheel that cost $1,252.89, illustrating the direct financial impact of the tariffs.

evidence.source_document: Brief in Support of Motion for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction
evidence.text: Montana’s beef producers, oil refineries, and wheat, barley and canola growers will be hard hit by the tariffs.

extracted.value: The tariffs are expected to harm Montana’s beef producers, oil refineries, and wheat, barley, and canola growers, increasing costs and potentially disrupting the state’s economy.

evidence.source_document: Brief in Support of Motion for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction
evidence.text: The “Fact Sheet” accompanying Executive Order 14193 includes Canada only in the first two bullets under “Addressing an Emergency Situation” that encompasses Canada, Mexico and China without differentiating among the countries.

extracted.value: The Fact Sheet accompanying Executive Order 14193 mentions Canada only in the first two bullets under 'Addressing an Emergency Situation', indicating a limited scope of the emergency claim.

evidence.source_document: Brief in Support of Motion for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction
evidence.text: The second section of the “Fact Sheet” states that “tariffs are a powerful, proven source of leverage for protecting the national interest.”

extracted.value: The Fact Sheet asserts that tariffs are a powerful, proven source of leverage for protecting the national interest.

evidence.source_document: Brief in Support of Motion for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction
evidence.text: Montana shares 14 Canadian border crossings with British Columbia, Alberta, and Saskatchewan provinces along its 545 mile, 877 kilometer northern border. The most heavily travelled ports are Sweetgrass, Roosville, and Piegan.

extracted.value: Montana shares 14 Canadian border crossings with British Columbia, Alberta, and Saskatchewan, with the most heavily travelled ports being Sweetgrass, Roosville, and Piegan.

evidence.source_document: Brief in Support of Motion for Preliminary and Permanent Injunction
evidence.text: Plaintiffs are enrolled members of the Blackfeet Tribe. Plaintiff Susan Webber is an enrolled member of the Blackfeet Nation and an elected representative of the Blackfeet and Confederated Salish and Kootenai Nations of Montana.

extracted.value: Plaintiffs are enrolled members of the Blackfeet Tribe and the Blackfeet Nation, and are actively engaged in cross‑border trade and commerce.

evidence.location: IV. FACTS COMMON TO ALL COUNTS
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: The border on the 49th parallel came to the Indigenous people of Montana.

extracted.value: The border on the 49th parallel came to the Indigenous people of Montana.

evidence.location: IV. FACTS COMMON TO ALL COUNTS
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: The Indigenous people did not come to the border.

extracted.value: The Indigenous people did not come to the border.

evidence.location: IV. FACTS COMMON TO ALL COUNTS
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: They did not participate in its creation.

extracted.value: They did not participate in its creation.

evidence.location: IV. FACTS COMMON TO ALL COUNTS
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: By history and law, the Indigenous people are exempt from the border’s artifice.

extracted.value: By history and law, the Indigenous people are exempt from the border’s artifice.

evidence.location: IV. FACTS COMMON TO ALL COUNTS
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Prior to the construct of nations on the 49th parallel Indigenous people travelled and engaged in commerce across the northwest plains.

extracted.value: Prior to the construct of nations on the 49th parallel Indigenous people travelled and engaged in commerce across the northwest plains.

evidence.location: IV. FACTS COMMON TO ALL COUNTS
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Post creation of a border at the 49th parallel, Indigenous people travelled and conducted commerce exempt from duties under the Jay Treaty of 1794.

extracted.value: Post creation of a border at the 49th parallel, Indigenous people travelled and conducted commerce exempt from duties under the Jay Treaty of 1794.

evidence.location: IV. FACTS COMMON TO ALL COUNTS
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: The border between the United States and Canada is the longest international boundary in the world.

extracted.value: The border between the United States and Canada is the longest international boundary in the world.

evidence.location: IV. FACTS COMMON TO ALL COUNTS
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: The border bisects historic homelands of more than thirty tribes, including members of the 'Wabanaki and Iroquois Confederacies, the Ojibwe, Ottawa, Lakota, Salish, Colville, several tribes of western Washington, and the Haida, Tlingit, and Tsimshian of Alaska and Canada.'

extracted.value: The border bisects historic homelands of more than thirty tribes, including members of the 'Wabanaki and Iroquois Confederacies, the Ojibwe, Ottawa, Lakota, Salish, Colville, several tribes of western Washington, and the Haida, Tlingit, and Tsimshian of Alaska and Canada.'

evidence.location: IV. FACTS COMMON TO ALL COUNTS
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: The Blackfeet Confederacy and the Akwesasne Mohawks are examples of sovereign tribal nations whose homelands straddle the 3,987 mile U.S. Canada border.

extracted.value: The Blackfeet Confederacy and the Akwesasne Mohawks are examples of sovereign tribal nations whose homelands straddle the 3,987 mile U.S. Canada border.

evidence.location: IV. FACTS COMMON TO ALL COUNTS
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: The Blackfeet Confederacy crosses the border and encompasses Tribes recognized by both Canada and America.

extracted.value: The Blackfeet Confederacy crosses the border and encompasses Tribes recognized by both Canada and America.

evidence.location: IV. FACTS COMMON TO ALL COUNTS
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: Montana shares 14 Canadian border crossings with British Columbia, Alberta, and Saskatchewan provinces along its 545 mile, 877 kilometer northern border.

extracted.value: Montana shares 14 Canadian border crossings with British Columbia, Alberta, and Saskatchewan provinces along its 545 mile, 877 kilometer northern border.

evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief
evidence.text: The most heavily travelled ports are Sweetgrass, Roosville, and Piegan.
